title: The Hottest New Credit Deals in Europe Are Anything to Do With Defense
summary: As NATO leaders huddled in The Hague in late June to iron out a plan to radically boost military spending, bankers in London were busy adding up the investor orders for a bond being offered by a little-known Czech maker of armored vehicles and ammunition.

title: Thyssenkrupp Eyes Naval Unit Spinoff to Tap Europe Defense Boom
summary: Thyssenkrupp AG is moving to cut loose its warship unit, hoping to ride a surge in European defense spending while stepping back from a business that has long been slow, costly, and hard to scale.
fullContent: Thyssenkrupp AG is moving to cut loose its warship unit, hoping to ride a surge in European defense spending while stepping back from a business that has long been slow, costly, and hard to scale.

title: Romania to Hold Rates on Inflation Spike Risk
summary: Romania is poised to keep borrowing costs unchanged ahead of an expected surge in inflation from a wave of tax hikes designed to help curb the budget deficit.

title: Trump’s Surprise Fed Pick Buys Him Time on Chair Selection
summary: President Donald Trump’s move to fill a slot at the Federal Reserve on a temporary basis offers him a chance to install an ally at the central bank, while giving him more time to weigh an even larger decision: who will be the next Fed Chair.
fullContent: President Donald Trump’s move to fill a slot at the Federal Reserve on a temporary basis offers him a chance to install an ally at the central bank, while giving him more time to weigh an even larger decision: who will be the next Fed Chair.

title: UK Resets Ties With Zimbabwe in Push for Critical Minerals
summary: Zimbabwe and the UK are rekindling diplomatic ties after almost three decades of tension, driven by a global surge in demand for critical minerals that’s led the former colonial power to pursue $1 billion in deals with the resource-rich nation.
fullContent: Zimbabwe and the UK are rekindling diplomatic ties after almost three decades of tension, driven by a global surge in demand for critical minerals that’s led the former colonial power to pursue $1 billion in deals with the resource-rich nation.
